0.name: Apple Scab
0.solution1: Water in the evening or early morning hours (avoid overhead irrigation) to give the leaves time to dry out before infection can occur.
0.solution2: Spread a 3- to 6-inch layer of compost under trees, keeping it away from the trunk, to cover soil and prevent splash dispersal of the fungal spores.
0.solution3: For best control, spray liquid copper soap early, two weeks before symptoms normally appear.

1.name: Apple Black Rot
1.solution1: Keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.
1.solution2: During the winter, check for red cankers and remove them by cutting them out or pruning away the affected limbs at least six inches (15 cm.) beyond the wound.
1.solution3: General-purpose fungicides, like copper-based sprays and lime sulfur can be used to control black rot.

2.name: Cedar Apple Rust
2.solution1: Remove galls from infected junipers. (In some cases, juniper plants should be removed entirely.)
2.solution2: Apply preventative, disease-fighting fungicides labeled for use on apples weekly, starting with bud break, to protect trees from spores being released by the juniper host.
2.solution3: On juniper, rust can be controlled by spraying plants with a copper solution (0.5 to 2.0 oz/ gallon of water) at least four times between late August and late October.

5.name: Cherry Powdery Mildew
5.solution1: Maintain a consistent program from shuck fall through harvest.
5.solution2: Consider post-harvest preventative measures (e.g. application of sulfur, prevent trees from pushing for leaf growth) to obstruct the fungus from overwintering.
5.solution3: Keep the disease off of the leaves.

7.name: Gray Leaf Spot of Corn
7.solution1: Crop rotation and tillage reduce survival of the fungus.
7.solution3: By removing weeds, above ground airflow to the crop is increased, relative humidity is decreased, and it limits infection at the most susceptible times.

8.name: Common Rust of Corn
8.solution1: Maize rusts are generally controlled by the use of resistant maize hybrids, and by foliar applications of fungicides on sweet corn.
8.solution2: The use of resistant varieties is the best way of managing rust diseases, two types of resistance exist: partial resistant and qualitative resistance.
8.solution3: Protectant fungicide e.g., chlorothalonil and mancozeb are recommended: .

9.name: Northern leaf blight of Corn
9.solution1: Scouting fields and monitoring local conditions is vital to control this disease.
9.solution2: Reduce the amount of infected residue left in a field, manage weeds to improve airflow and reduce humidity.
9.solution3: The use of foliar fungicides for corn can be used to control NCLB

11.name: Black rot of Grapes
11.solution1: Apply sanitation methods to optimally grow grape crops.
11.solution2: The most common fungicides that prove to be excellent for controlling black rot are Sovran 50WG, Flint 50WG, Abound Flowable (2.08F), and Pristine 38WDG.

12.name: Esca (Black Measles) of Grape
12.solution1: Protect pruning wounds from fungal infections to minimize suspect fungi from colonizing fresh wounds.
12.solution2: Keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.

13.name: Isariopsis Leaf Spot of Grapes
13.solution2: Keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.

15.name: Huanglongbing (Citrus greening) of Orange
15.solution1: Once a tree has citrus greening, there is no cure.
15.solution2: It is incredibly important to remove trees that have citrus greening disease.
15.solution3: Keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.

16.name: Peach Bacterial spot
16.solution1: Use Oxytetracycline as it is generally considered the most effective compound and the least prone to phytotoxicity problems (damage to plant tissue).
16.solution2: Syllit+captan can be used to control it
16.solution3: Repeated applications are typically necessary for even minimal disease control.

18.name: Bacterial Leaf Spot of Pepper
18.solution1: Using resistant varieties such as, F1 of Autry, Green Flash, Labelle, Ninja, Outsider, Playmaker, Prowler, Raven, Samurai etc.
18.solution2: Wash seeds for 40 minutes in diluted Clorox (two parts Clorox plus eight parts water) to reduce the bacterial population.
18.solution3: Copper sprays can be used to control bacterial leaf spot.

20.name: Potato Early blight
20.solution1: Remove all garden crop residue, a thorough cleanup is essential.
20.solution3: Control insects as Aphids and White flies can spread diseases.

21.name: Potato Late Blight
21.solution1: It is controlled by eliminating cull piles and volunteer potatoes, using proper harvesting and storage practices.
21.solution3: Air drainage to facilitate the drying of foliage each day is important.

25.name: Powdery Mildew on Squash
25.solution1: Sulfur and Stylet oil are effective products for powdery mildew control.
25.solution2: Neem oil is also an effective combatant for managing powdery mildew.
25.solution3: Fixed copper fungicides can also be used to manage it.

26.name: Strawberries With Leaf Scorch
26.solution1: Proper garden sanitation is must needed.
26.solution2: Frequent establishment of new strawberry transplants.
26.solution3: Maintain a consistent strawberry harvest, as older plants are more likely to show signs of severe infection.

28.name: Bacterial Spot of Tomato
28.solution1: A plant with bacterial spot cannot be cured.
28.solution2: Remove symptomatic plants from the field or greenhouse to prevent the spread of bacteria to Healthy plants.
28.solution3: Keep all the fallen debris and dead fruit cleaned up and away from the tree.

29.name: Tomato Early Blight
29.solution1: Try resistant varieties, which are new but very worthwhile.
29.solution2: Grow tomatoes at wide spacing in full sun, so their leaves dry promptly each morning and after rains.
29.solution3: Avoid wetting the foliage when watering tomatoes.

30.name: Late Blight On Tomatoes
30.solution1: Sanitation is the first step in controlling tomato late blight.
30.solution2: Clean up all debris and fallen fruit from the garden area.
30.solution3: Fungicides that contain maneb, mancozeb, chlorothanolil, or fixed copper can help protect plants from late tomato blight.

31.name: Leaf Mold of Tomato
31.solution1: When planting, use only certified disease-free seed or treated seed.
31.solution2: Remove and destroy all crop debris post-harvest.
31.solution3: Use fans and avoid overhead watering to minimize leaf wetness. Also, stake and prune plants to increase ventilation.

32.name: Septoria Leaf Spot of Tomato
32.solution1: Pinch off leaves with leaf spots and bury them in the compost pile.
32.solution2: Do not remove more than a third of the plant's leaves.
32.solution3: Keep leaves dry to reduce spreading the disease.

33.name: Tomato Red Spider Mite
33.solution1: Avoid continuous cropping of tomato and related plants which makes it difficult to control red spider mites.
33.solution2: Spray water regularly on plants to reduce dust, spider mites do well in dusty conditions.
33.solution3: You can also use miticides which are specific for mites e.g. Dynamec (active ingredient abamectin), Oberon (spiromesifen) or Omite (propargite).

34.name: Target Spot on Tomatoes
34.solution1: Rotate crops and don’t plant tomatoes in areas where other disease-prone plants have been located in the past year.
34.solution2: Water tomato plants in the morning so the leaves have time to dry.
34.solution3: Remove old plant debris at the end of the growing season, otherwise, the spores will travel from debris to newly planted tomatoes in the following growing season.

35.name: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus
35.solution1: Use only virus-and whitefly-free tomato and transplants.
35.solution2: Imidacloprid or thiamethoxam should be used in transplant houses at least seven days before shipping.
35.solution3: Transplants should be treated with Capture (bifenthrin) or Venom (dinotefuran)

36.name: Tomato Mosaic Virus
36.solution1: There is no cure for the Mosaic Virus.
36.solution2: Disinfect gardening tools after every use.
36.solution3: Remove all infected plants and destroy them. Do not put them in the compost pile, as the virus may persist in infected plant matter.
